title: Worldpay floats in largest London IPO this year
text:

Tue, Oct 13, 2015, 11:09 BST - UK Markets close in 5 hrs 21 mins Worldpay floats in largest London IPO this year By Lauren Davidson | Telegraph – 28 minutes ago 33.81 -0.31 
The payments processor priced its IPO at 240p per share, in the middle of its initial range 
Worldpay has floated on the London Stock Exchange (Other OTC: LDNXF - news ) in the UK's largest IPO this year , giving the payments processor a market cap of £4.8bn. 
Shares (Berlin: DI6.BE - news ) jumped 6pc in conditional trading, in which City institutions trade the stock ahead of open trading, which begins on October 16. 
The British company priced its IPO at 240p per share, in the middle of its initial 225p to 260p range. 
Worldpay found itself at the centre of a bidding war this summer, attracting offers from JP Morgan’s private equity arm, German-based payments company Wirecard (Xetra: 747206 - news ) , private equity firms Blackstone (NYSE: BX - news ) and Hellman & Friedman and French rival Ingenico (Paris: FR0000125346 - news ) , which valued the company at more than £6bn. 
The IPO will generate proceeds of £2.16m, of which Worldpay will receive £947.8m. 
The payments company's private equity owners will retain 48.7pc of the stock. 
"Today’s announcement is a significant milestone for Worldpay," said chief executive Philip Jansen. 
"We are proud to be a leader in global payments with a clear strategy for continued growth as a listed company. 
"We have already invested over £1bn in our technology, people and capabilities, helping us to become an advanced and sophisticated technology-led organisation with great potential." 
The UK company, which qualifies for FTSE 100 inclusion, processes £370bn in payments from 400,000 merchants every year and handles around 40pc of web-based transactions in Europe. 
In 2014, Worldpay made an underlying profit of £765m on revenues of £3.6bn. In the first six months of this year, sales rose 13pc to £465.7m, pushing profits up by the same amount to £182.6m. 
As of the end of September, the London stock market had welcomed 93 flotations raising £5.3bn this year, a significant drop from the £11bn generated from 136 listings in the same period last year, according to Reuters.
